docs.title: CORE — Community Obsidian Resource Exchange
docs.text:
CORE is an open, community-driven knowledge base for computer science, software engineering, cybersecurity, cloud, and AI.

The project is designed to take learners from beginner → advanced through structured notes, hands-on labs, and concise cheatsheets — all built openly by the community.

docs.title: 🧠 Notes
docs.text: Organized by skill level and domain: - Beginner → fundamentals and mental models - Intermediate → practical systems and workflows - Advanced → specialization and deep dives

docs.title: 🧪 Labs
docs.text: Hands-on exercises designed to reinforce concepts through practice.

docs.title: 📄 Cheatsheets
docs.text: Quick-reference material for commands, syntax, and workflows.

docs.title: Who This Is For
docs.text:
• Self-taught learners
  • Students and career switchers
  • Working professionals refreshing fundamentals
  • Contributors who want to teach at scale

docs.title: How to Contribute
docs.text: If you want to help build CORE: - Read CONTRIBUTING.md - Use the templates in /templates - Start with a beginner note or lab

docs.title: Status
docs.text:
🚧 CORE is actively under construction. Structure is stable; content is growing.

Start with Beginner → Computer Science → What is a Computer?

docs.title: CORE — Community Obsidian Resource Exchange
docs.text:
An open, community-driven vault of notes for computer science, coding, and cybersecurity.

🌱 Our goal: Create the world’s most comprehensive open learning resource, making it easy for beginners to start and grow all the way to advanced topics like red teaming, cloud security, and AI.

docs.title: 🚀 Mission
docs.text:
• Make knowledge open, structured, and easy to explore.
  • Help beginners and experts alike learn, teach, and contribute.
  • Keep resources free and community-owned.

docs.title: CORE Roadmap
docs.text: CORE is built in public and evolves in stages.

docs.title: Phase 1 — Foundations (current)
docs.text:
• Stable taxonomy
  • Beginner core notes
  • MkDocs site online

docs.title: Phase 2 — Expansion
docs.text:
• Intermediate systems content
  • Hands-on labs
  • Contributor onboarding

docs.title: Phase 3 — Depth
docs.text:
• Advanced security, cloud, and AI
  • Community curation
  • Quality scoring and reviews

docs.title: Library
docs.text:
Reference layer for CORE: definitions, tools, patterns, checklists, playbooks, and curated reading.

Use this when you need a quick, reliable reference rather than a lesson.

docs.text: Reference hub for Ai.

• definitions and key concepts

docs.title: Checklists
docs.text:
Short, executable checklists you can run before shipping or testing.

Examples: - New Linux box hardening - API security baseline - Cloud account bootstrap

docs.title: Identity & access
docs.text:
• [ ] Create non-root user; disable password SSH if possible
  • [ ] Confirm sudoers minimal
  • [ ] Disable unused accounts/services

docs.title: Patch state
docs.text:
• [ ] sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade
  • [ ] Reboot if kernel upgraded

docs.title: Services
docs.text:
• [ ] systemctl --type=service --state=running
  • [ ] Disable anything not needed

docs.title: Network exposure
docs.text:
• [ ] ss -tulpn review listeners
  • [ ] Firewall enabled (ufw/nftables)

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
• [ ] journalctl -p warning -b
  • [ ] Verify logs stored and rotated

docs.title: Layer 3/4
docs.text:
• [ ] ip a (correct IP?)
  • [ ] ip r (default route present?)
  • [ ] ping -c 1 1.1.1.1 (raw connectivity)
  • [ ] ss -tulpn (service actually listening)

docs.title: DNS
docs.text:
• [ ] dig +short example.com
  • [ ] Check resolver config: /etc/resolv.conf

docs.title: HTTP
docs.text:
• [ ] curl -v https://host
  • [ ] Check TLS errors and redirects

docs.title: Tracing
docs.text: • [ ] traceroute host or mtr host

docs.title: Accounts & access
docs.text:
• [ ] MFA enabled on critical accounts
  • [ ] Least privilege roles/policies
  • [ ] No shared admin accounts

docs.title: Secrets
docs.text:
• [ ] No secrets committed to git
  • [ ] Secrets stored in a vault / GitHub Secrets
  • [ ] Rotation plan exists

docs.title: Dependencies
docs.text:
• [ ] Pin versions where possible
  • [ ] Audit high-risk deps
  • [ ] Remove unused deps

docs.title: Logging & detection
docs.text:
• [ ] Auth logs enabled and retained
  • [ ] Alerts for suspicious login patterns
  • [ ] Time sync enabled (NTP)

docs.title: Backup & recovery
docs.text:
• [ ] Backups exist
  • [ ] Restore tested

docs.title: A
docs.text:
• ACL (Access Control List) — rules defining who/what can access a resource.
  • ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) — maps IP addresses to MAC addresses on a LAN.

docs.title: C
docs.text: • CIDR — notation for IP ranges (e.g., 10.0.0.0/24).

docs.title: D
docs.text: • DNS — resolves names to IP addresses.

docs.title: E
docs.text: • EUID/EGID — effective user/group IDs used for permission checks.

docs.title: F
docs.text: • Firewall — rules that allow/deny network traffic based on policy.

docs.title: I
docs.text:
• IAM — identity and access management (users/roles/policies).
  • ICMP — control messages used by tools like ping.

docs.title: P
docs.text:
• Port — logical endpoint for a network service (0–65535).
  • Process — running program instance with PID.

docs.title: S
docs.text:
• SSH — secure remote shell protocol.
  • SUID — permission bit that runs a binary as the file owner.

docs.title: T
docs.text: • TLS — cryptographic protocol behind HTTPS.

docs.title: Core concepts
docs.text:
• Everything is a file: devices, sockets, and config are exposed as filesystem objects.
  • Users/Groups: permissions are evaluated via UID/GID and file mode bits.
  • Processes: each process has PID, owner, environment, open files, and network sockets.

docs.title: Common tasks
docs.text:
• Inspect files/dirs: ls -la, stat
  • Search: find, grep -R, ripgrep (rg)
  • Processes: ps aux, top, htop, pgrep, kill
  • Services (systemd): systemctl status|start|stop <svc>
  • Logs: journalctl -u <svc> -e, /var/log/*
  • Networking: ip a, ss -tulpn, curl, dig

docs.title: Permission model (quick)
docs.text:
• Mode bits: rwxrwxrwx for user/group/other
  • Ownership: chown user:group file
  • Special bits: SUID/SGID/sticky

docs.title: Links
docs.text:
• Beginner notes: ../../notes/beginner/linux/index.md
  • Checklist: ../checklists/linux-baseline.md
  • Cheatsheet: ../../notes/cheatsheets/linux-cli.md

docs.title: Mental model
docs.text:
• IP routes packets between hosts
  • TCP is reliable, ordered, connection-oriented
  • UDP is connectionless, faster, no delivery guarantees
  • DNS maps names → IPs
  • HTTP is an application protocol usually over TCP (HTTPS adds TLS)

docs.title: Common commands
docs.text:
• Interfaces/IP: ip a, ip r
  • Sockets: ss -tulpn
  • DNS: dig A example.com, dig +short
  • HTTP: curl -v https://example.com
  • Tracing: traceroute, mtr
  • Packet capture: tcpdump -i <iface>

docs.title: Ports (quick)
docs.text:
• 22 SSH
  • 53 DNS
  • 80 HTTP
  • 443 HTTPS

docs.text:

docs.title: Patterns
docs.text:
Reusable mental models and implementation patterns.

Examples: - Least privilege (IAM) - Defense in depth - Zero trust - Logging strategy - Backup/restore testing

docs.title: Playbooks
docs.text:
Operational response guides.

Examples: - Suspicious login investigation - Credential leak response - Vulnerability triage workflow

docs.title: Trigger
docs.text:
• Unexpected login alert
  • Impossible travel / new device
  • Multiple failed attempts

docs.title: Triage (10 minutes)
docs.text:
• Identify account, timestamp, source IP, user agent
  • Confirm whether user initiated the login
  • Check MFA events

docs.title: Containment
docs.text:
• Reset password and revoke active sessions/tokens
  • Rotate keys if any were exposed
  • Temporarily lock account if needed

docs.title: Investigation
docs.text:
• Review recent privileged actions
  • Check for new SSH keys / API tokens / OAuth grants
  • Search logs for lateral movement or data access

docs.title: Recovery
docs.text:
• Restore access to user with clean device + MFA
  • Remove malicious keys/tokens/apps
  • Document and add detection rules

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
• Timeline
  • Evidence (IPs, UAs, tokens)
  • Root cause and prevention

docs.title: Reading Lists
docs.text:
Curated learning lists per domain.

Format: - Resource - Why it matters - Prereqs - Time estimate

docs.title: Core model
docs.text: Security = managing risk by controlling: - identity (who/what) - access (can they do it) - exposure (is it reachable) - impact (what happens if compromised) - detection (will you notice)

docs.title: Foundations
docs.text:
• Threat modeling (assets, actors, attack paths)
  • AuthN vs AuthZ
  • Least privilege
  • Secure defaults
  • Logging and incident response

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
Curated tooling used across CS, security, cloud, and development workflows.

Suggested sections: - Editors/IDEs - Shell tooling - Networking tools - Security tools - Cloud tooling

docs.title: Core model
docs.text:
• Browser/Client sends requests to a server
  • Requests are shaped by URL + method + headers + body
  • Servers respond with status + headers + body
  • State is typically carried via cookies, tokens, or server-side session stores

docs.title: Key concepts
docs.text:
• Methods: GET/POST/PUT/PATCH/DELETE
  • Status codes: 2xx success, 3xx redirect, 4xx client error, 5xx server error
  • Cookies: storage + session identifiers
  • CORS: controls cross-origin reads in browsers
  • Auth: sessions vs tokens (JWT) vs API keys

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• curl (raw HTTP)
  • browser devtools (network tab)
  • openssl s_client (TLS inspection)

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: A computer is a machine that takes input, processes it according to instructions, stores data, and produces output. Most computers share the same fundamental architecture: computation (CPU), memory (RAM), storage (SSD/HDD), and input/output devices. Understanding these components helps you reason about performance, debugging, and how software interacts with hardware.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: • None

docs.title: Input → Process → Output
docs.text:
• Input: data enters the system (keyboard, mouse, files, network)
  • Process: instructions execute on the CPU
  • Output: results leave the system (screen, files, network)

docs.title: CPU (Central Processing Unit)
docs.text:
• Executes instructions
  • Performance depends on cores, clock speed, cache, and workload type

docs.title: Memory (RAM)
docs.text:
• Fast, temporary storage
  • Cleared when power is lost
  • Insufficient RAM leads to swapping and slowdowns

docs.title: Storage (SSD/HDD)
docs.text:
• Persistent data storage
  • SSDs are faster than HDDs for most workloads

docs.title: Input/Output (I/O)
docs.text:
• Communication paths between components
  • Disk, network, USB, display all count as I/O

docs.title: Commands / Code
docs.text:
Check system information on Linux:

```bash uname -a lscpu free -h lsblk

docs.title: Git Fundamentals
docs.text: Git is the standard tool for tracking changes and collaborating.

docs.text: Linux is a family of operating systems used heavily in servers, cloud, containers, and security tooling.

docs.title: Cheatsheets
docs.text: Quick reference material will live here.

docs.title: Quick curl
docs.text:
• Headers only: curl -I https://example.com
  • Verbose: curl -v https://example.com
  • POST JSON:
  • curl -X POST https://host/api -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -d '{"a":1}'

docs.title: Common status codes
docs.text:
• 200 OK
  • 301/302 Redirect
  • 400 Bad Request
  • 401 Unauthorized
  • 403 Forbidden
  • 404 Not Found
  • 429 Too Many Requests
  • 500 Internal Server Error
  • 502/503 Gateway/Service issues

docs.title: Cookies
docs.text:
• View: curl -I https://host
  • Send: curl -H 'Cookie: name=value' https://host

docs.title: Files
docs.text:
• List: ls -la
  • View: cat, less
  • Search: grep -R "term" .
  • Find: find . -name "*.log"

docs.title: Processes
docs.text:
• List: ps aux
  • Live: top
  • Kill: kill -9 <PID> (use carefully)

docs.title: Networking
docs.text:
• IP: ip a
  • Routes: ip r
  • Sockets: ss -tulpn

docs.title: DNS
docs.text:
• dig +short A example.com
  • dig +trace example.com

docs.title: HTTP
docs.text:
• curl -I https://example.com
  • curl -v https://example.com

docs.title: Ports / sockets
docs.text:
• ss -tulpn
  • nc -vz host 443

docs.title: What you should be able to do after this section
docs.text:
• Read and reason about an HTTP request/response
  • Explain cookies, sessions, and common auth flows
  • Debug basic web issues using curl and browser devtools

docs.title: Core topics
docs.text:
• HTTP messages (start line, headers, body)
  • Redirects and caching
  • Cookies and sessions
  • Authentication & authorization basics

docs.title: Labs
docs.text: Hands-on labs will live here.

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Build intuition for request/response anatomy, redirects, headers, and TLS.

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text:
1) Inspect headers: - curl -I https://example.com

2) Follow redirects: - curl -IL https://example.com

3) See full exchange: - curl -v https://example.com

4) Inspect TLS: - echo | openssl s_client -connect example.com:443 -servername example.com 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -issuer -subject -dates

docs.title: Success criteria
docs.text: You can explain: - why redirects happen - which headers matter for caching/security - what the certificate issuer/expiry means

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: Confirm you can inspect interfaces, routes, DNS, and HTTP from a Linux host.

docs.title: Tasks
docs.text:
1) Show interfaces: - ip a

2) Show routes: - ip r

3) Resolve DNS: - dig +short example.com

4) Test HTTP: - curl -I https://example.com

5) Check listening ports: - ss -tulpn

docs.title: Success criteria
docs.text: You can explain: - what IP you have - your default route - DNS resolution result - HTTP response status
